caption: Figure 1: Images of Yk on Z2. The set of integer points in the trapezoid is the feasible region X. Left: the gray area represents Yk−1 consisting of points reachable from Xk−1. Middle: if ik = 0 (case 1), Xk−1 = Xk holds and Yk−1 shrinks to Yk, the darker area, since the constraint on y(V) gets tighter. Right: if ik = i₁ (cases 2 and 3), the area, Yk, reachable from Xk = Xk−1 + ei₁ shifts along ei₁.
description: This figure shows the visualization of the sets Yk in a two-dimensional space (Z2).  Each panel represents a different scenario, illustrating how the set of feasible points (Yk) changes depending on the choice of ik (update direction).  The feasible region is a trapezoid, and the gray area represents the set of points reachable at each step of the algorithm. Case 1 shows the scenario where no update is made (ik = 0). Case 2 and 3 depict the scenarios when an update is performed (ik ≠ 0), showing the shift of Yk along the update direction ei₁. The figure aids in understanding the proof of Theorem 3.1, which establishes the robustness of the greedy algorithm to local errors in M-concave function maximization.
section: Robustness of greedy M¹-concave function maximization to local errors
